data.title: Whirlpool (WHR) Is Down 19.0% After Dilutive Recapitalization and Appaloosa Rebuke - Has The Bull Case Changed?
data.description:

  • Appaloosa’s public rebuke of Whirlpool’s board and management, including calls to invite potential partners or buyers, injects governance and control questions directly into the investment case for the appliance maker.

To own Whirlpool today, you need to believe the company can stabilize demand in its mature core markets while lifting margins through cost efficiencies and new product introductions, despite weak housing and intense competition. The recent US$2.0 billion-plus equity and preferred recapitalization, and the backlash over dilution, now make capital allocation and governance a key near term catalyst and risk, as investors weigh balance sheet repair against potential pressure on per share earnings.

Among recent announcements, the late February 2026 equity and preferred offerings, totaling roughly US$475 million in common shares and about US$1.58 billion in preferred and depositary shares, matter most here. The proceeds are earmarked for debt repayment and corporate purposes, directly affecting Whirlpool’s capital structure at a time when its dividend coverage, leverage and profitability are already under scrutiny, and when consensus still expects only modest revenue growth and mid single digit margins.

data.title: Colgate-Palmolive 2030 Plan Links AI Spending To Brand And Margin Goals
data.description:
• Colgate-Palmolive (NYSE:CL) has started executing its 2030 Strategic Plan, with a focus on global brand strength, product innovation grounded in scientific research, and broader demand generation.
  • The company is rolling out advanced digital tools and AI across its supply chain and organization as part of this multi-year plan.
  • The plan is intended to reshape how Colgate-Palmolive competes in oral care, personal care, home care, and pet nutrition categories worldwide.

For investors watching NYSE:CL, this new plan arrives with the shares at $99.14 and multi year returns that include 43.9% over 3 years and 46.7% over 5 years. In the shorter term, the stock shows returns of 4.3% over the past week, 16.6% over the past month, and 27.6% year to date. Together, these figures help frame how the market has been pricing recent company developments.

As Colgate-Palmolive moves through the early phases of this 2030 plan, the main questions for investors will center on how effectively it uses AI, digital tools, and scientific research to support its brands and operations. Future reporting periods will help show whether this execution approach changes the company’s competitive position and efficiency in a meaningful way.

Stay updated on the most important news stories for Colgate-Palmolive by adding it to your watchlist or portfolio. Alternatively, explore our Community to discover new perspectives on Colgate-Palmolive.

We've flagged 3 risks for Colgate-Palmolive. See which could impact your investment.

The 2030 Strategic Plan signals that Colgate-Palmolive is trying to tighten the link between its core strengths, such as brand equity in oral and personal care, and the operational engine behind them. For you as an investor, the interesting part is less the buzzwords around AI and more whether these tools genuinely lower costs, shorten product cycles and improve on-shelf execution across both developed and emerging markets. Using data, analytics and AI-powered tools in the supply chain and marketing could help Colgate-Palmolive respond more quickly to consumer trends and retailer demands, including in e-commerce channels where competitors like Procter & Gamble, Unilever and Nestlé are active.

Advertisement

How This Fits Into The Colgate-Palmolive Narrative

  • The plan to expand omnichannel reach and use digital tools is consistent with the narrative that positions emerging markets and premium oral care as long term growth drivers supported by better data and targeted marketing.
  • Execution risk on restructuring and productivity programs could challenge the idea that cost savings will always be easy to reinvest while still supporting margins, especially if category growth in key markets is slower than analysts expect.
  • The emphasis on AI and predictive analytics in the supply chain is an area that may not be fully captured in older narratives that focused more on product and geographic expansion than on back end efficiency gains.

Knowing what a company is worth starts with understanding its story. Check out one of the top narratives in the Simply Wall St Community for Colgate-Palmolive to help decide what it's worth to you.

The Risks and Rewards Investors Should Consider

  • ⚠️ Colgate-Palmolive is committing to multi year productivity and restructuring efforts, and if these projects disrupt operations or fall short on savings, the payoff from the 2030 plan could be limited.
  • ⚠️ The company faces category pressures and private label competition in several regions, so heavier digital and AI investment may not fully offset weaker volumes or pricing pressure in oral care and pet nutrition.
  • 🎁 Colgate-Palmolive has strong global brands and exposure to emerging markets, and the 2030 plan aims to use science led product development and data driven marketing to support that position across oral care, personal care, home care and pet nutrition.
  • 🎁 Analysts have identified rewards such as forecast earnings growth, a reliable dividend and a valuation that some models view as below estimated fair value, which frame how this long term plan might appeal to different investor profiles.

What To Watch Going Forward

From here, you may want to watch for concrete milestones on the 2030 plan, such as evidence of supply chain savings, new product launches backed by scientific claims and traction in e-commerce and omnichannel partnerships. Commentary around Hill’s Pet Nutrition and emerging markets like Latin America and India will also matter, given their role in previous analyst views of Colgate-Palmolive’s growth mix. Finally, pay attention to how management talks about reinvesting productivity gains into advertising and R&D, and whether that shows up in brand share trends relative to peers such as Procter & Gamble and Unilever.

Approach 1: Public Storage Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis

The DCF model here takes Public Storage’s adjusted funds from operations, projects them into the future, then discounts those cash flows back to today’s dollars to estimate what the business might be worth right now.

On this basis, Public Storage is modeled using a 2 stage Free Cash Flow to Equity approach built on adjusted funds from operations. The latest twelve month free cash flow is about $2.78b. Analyst and extrapolated estimates suggest free cash flow reaching around $3.70b by 2030, with a path that moves through projected figures such as $2.81b in 2026 and $3.46b in 2029, all in US dollars.

After discounting these projected cash flows, the model arrives at an estimated intrinsic value of about $462.30 per share. Compared with the current share price of around $307, this implies a 33.6% discount, which indicates that the shares screen as undervalued under this particular set of assumptions.

Approach 2: Public Storage Price vs Earnings

For a profitable company like Public Storage, the P/E ratio is a straightforward way to see what investors are paying for each dollar of earnings. It captures both what the business is earning today and how the market is weighing its prospects and risks.

In general, higher growth expectations and lower perceived risk can support a higher P/E, while slower growth or higher risk usually line up with a lower, more cautious multiple. The question is not whether a P/E is high or low in isolation, but whether it makes sense given the company’s profile.

Public Storage currently trades on a P/E of 33.99x. That sits above the Specialized REITs industry average of 15.86x, and below the peer group average of 41.55x. Simply Wall St’s Fair Ratio for Public Storage is 34.36x, which is its proprietary estimate of a suitable P/E given the company’s earnings growth, industry, profit margins, market cap and key risks. This Fair Ratio can be more informative than a simple peer or industry comparison because it tries to account for the specific mix of growth, risk and profitability that is unique to Public Storage.

With the current P/E of 33.99x very close to the Fair Ratio of 34.36x, the shares screen as ABOUT RIGHT on this metric.

Result: ABOUT RIGHT

data.title: Cloudflare Deepens Security Role With Post Quantum SASE And Mastercard Pact
data.description:
• Cloudflare launched what it calls the first complete Secure Access Service Edge platform with post-quantum encryption across its services.
  • The company also announced a cybersecurity partnership with Mastercard aimed at protecting critical infrastructure and small businesses with real time, risk driven defenses.

Cloudflare, trading on the NYSE under ticker NYSE:NET, sits at the intersection of networking and security. This move pushes more of its product stack into the security spotlight. The stock last closed at $172.19, with a 1 year return of 18.5% and a 3 year return of 179.6%. These figures put the announcements into focus for investors following the company's evolution. The 5 year return of 156.9% offers a longer lens on how the market has treated Cloudflare's role in internet infrastructure.

In the near term, investors watching NYSE:NET are likely to focus on how post-quantum encryption and the Mastercard partnership translate into product adoption and customer stickiness. As quantum computing risk and attacks on payment systems and small businesses receive more attention, Cloudflare's positioning around end to end cryptography and real time threat screening may become a more central part of how the company is evaluated.
